intro: Amphicarpaea ciliata, commonly known as the hairy false indigo, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Fabaceae family, characterized by its compound leaves and pod-like fruits. The plant produces two types of flowers: one for sexual reproduction and another for asexual reproduction through its underground structures. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in wetlands and along stream banks. Its ornamental value and ecological importance make it a notable species in its native habitat.
